replies.msg:
係喎
咁無野
小學雞思維
不過兒登求學問個風氣真係太差
氣流

我認真答你
飛機之所以可以係空中飛 係因為機翼有足夠升力「托」起架飛機
咁機翼點樣可以產生足夠升力呢？就係要係機翼既空氣局部速度（風速）夠快

有幾個情況飛機會無啦啦跌
第一個就係失速 簡單黎講就係喺機翼既風速突然下降
到一個位產生得唔夠升力去托起架機
成因有上面巴打們所講既microburst, turbulence(所謂既氣流）, 晴空湍流
頭果兩個你都可以理解做風向突然急轉 變相令本身風速下降(vector)
Microburst特別小小既地方係佢既風會向下吹 變相令你架機跌得更快
所以升降時既microburst係好危險
因此機場依加都有足夠儀器去探測到佢地既出現 從而提醒升降中既機師

晴空湍流 就係指氣象雷達探測唔到既氣流
正常飛機師見前面天氣太惡劣既話一係會繞路走 一係就會原地轉圈直到前面天氣好轉
但晴空亂流因為你睇唔到 所以你無得避 亦都係我覺得樓主發生既情況
（依加雷達可能睇到？等巴打指教）
仲有啲罕見少少既原因例如飛機太高超速 同鄰近飛機/ 同地勢太近 呢啲日常都應該少見

有另一個可能性就係飛機降落既時候
機師想停留係更高既高度耐啲 從而慳油
就黎到機場既時候佢地會跌得比較快 都會發生類似既情況

再另一個就可能係樓主坐機尾
每次飛機轉pitch angle既時候 你都會覺得架飛機好似升/跌得好勁
想坐得舒服既話就坐近機翼前方啦
空姐坐住機師

風切變
兩個風向 形成真空層

quote.msg:
我認真答你
飛機之所以可以係空中飛 係因為機翼有足夠升力「托」起架飛機
咁機翼點樣可以產生足夠升力呢？就係要係機翼既空氣局部速度（風速）夠快

有幾個情況飛機會無啦啦跌
第一個就係失速 簡單黎講就係喺機翼既風速突然下降
到一個位產生得唔夠升力去托起架機
成因有上面巴打們所講既microburst, turbulence(所謂既氣流）, 晴空湍流
頭果兩個你都可以理解做風向突然急轉 變相令本身風速下降(vector)
Microburst特別小小既地方係佢既風會向下吹 變相令你架機跌得更快
所以升降時既microburst係好危險
因此機場依加都有足夠儀器去探測到佢地既出現 從而提醒升降中既機師

晴空湍流 就係指氣象雷達探測唔到既氣流
正常飛機師見前面天氣太惡劣既話一係會繞路走 一係就會原地轉圈直到前面天氣好轉
但晴空亂流因為你睇唔到 所以你無得避 亦都係我覺得樓主發生既情況
（依加雷達可能睇到？等巴打指教）
仲有啲罕見少少既原因例如飛機太高超速 同鄰近飛機/ 同地勢太近 呢啲日常都應該少見

有另一個可能性就係飛機降落既時候
機師想停留係更高既高度耐啲 從而慳油
就黎到機場既時候佢地會跌得比較快 都會發生類似既情況

再另一個就可能係樓主坐機尾
每次飛機轉pitch angle既時候 你都會覺得架飛機好似升/跌得好勁
想坐得舒服既話就坐近機翼前方啦

replies.msg: 詳細到令一個對呢方面冇認識嘅樓豬有少少概念

replies.msg:
其實唔係因為易stall而fuel efficient 而係swept wing先可以飛快啲 同jet engine 係呢個速度係fuel efficient d

Technically 成個recovery 要先用rudder去balance返個wing drop再recover and stabilise, altitude lost會比普通stall recovery多 而且理論上可以會wing drop完到另一邊wing drop

Slept wing design 通常但唔一定會有nose high in stall. Depends on the aircraft design esp centre of gravity

quote.msg:
其實唔係因為易stall而fuel efficient 而係swept wing先可以飛快啲 同jet engine 係呢個速度係fuel efficient d

Technically 成個recovery 要先用rudder去balance返個wing drop再recover and stabilise, altitude lost會比普通stall recovery多 而且理論上可以會wing drop完到另一邊wing drop

Slept wing design 通常但唔一定會有nose high in stall. Depends on the aircraft design esp centre of gravity
Modern aircraft will stall at the wing root first, there is a higher pitch angle at the root than the one at the wingtip
For Swept back design, airflow tends to flow towards and separates at the tip.

quote.msg:
其實唔係因為易stall而fuel efficient 而係swept wing先可以飛快啲 同jet engine 係呢個速度係fuel efficient d

Technically 成個recovery 要先用rudder去balance返個wing drop再recover and stabilise, altitude lost會比普通stall recovery多 而且理論上可以會wing drop完到另一邊wing drop

Slept wing design 通常但唔一定會有nose high in stall. Depends on the aircraft design esp centre of gravity
Modern aircraft will stall at the wing root first, there is a higher pitch angle at the root than the one at the wingtip
For Swept back design, airflow tends to flow towards and separates at the tip.

replies.msg:
起飛/降落時 大家會見到機翼尾有塊野伸出黎
果個叫副翼 令到機翼可以制造更加多升力
從而令飛機可以用一個低啲既速度升降
民航機一般好難失速 呢個係真
但睇你難既定義係咩
開左副翼之後 飛機既pitch angle會大好多
速度會比正常低好多 咁降落既時候又可以用少啲跑步黎剎停架飛機
原因係副翼會增加多好多阻力
而且佢會將啲風既方向引導向下
所以呢樣絕對唔係慳油既方案 飛機會用更加多既推力（油）去確保飛機保持係某個速度
我無記錯的話失速速度+10海浬=理想降落速度
有錯請指

機翼尖有一堆工程師發現如果將佢向上「咬」 的話 耗油量會比正常低幾%
所以依加新形飛機大多都採納呢種設計

replies.msg:
For aviation geeks:

Sweep

Swept wing is mostly used to delay wing approaching supersonic speed
Since the freestream at swept wing is = V(infinity) * cos theta
Where V(infinity) =freestream velocity and theta = angle of swept
At cruise the aircraft is flying at around 0.8Mach
So it is vital to keep the airflow (especially the negative pressure part of the wing) to be just below speed of sound in order to prevent shockwave
So yes this is to increase the fuel efficiency but not for T/O or landing

Flaps

As mentioned flaps are deployed to increase the skin friction and the camberness of the wing
Such that the aircraft could land at a relatively lower speed whilst having enough lift to stay airborne
Pitch is also the greatest when the aircraft is flying at stall speed
(If you recall, L is proportional to alpha and V)
So in order to generate the same amount of lift, the aircraft has to fly at a higher AoA
And eventually the flow no longer attaches to the wing > flow separation > stall
I am not familiar with the SOP, but a logical guess would be Vref + 10 = landing speed in case of windshear
At the same time to keep the pitch below the stall angle

Wing tip

Imagine a finite rectangular wing going through wind tunnel
Lift is produced due to the pressure difference as we expected
Since the upper part of the wing has a lower pressure
Hence at the end of the wing the high pressure airflow (bottom) tends to roll up
Vortex/ downwash is hence generated, and by Newton’s 3rd law that would decrease the effective AoA
Wing tip is then invented that the airflow will keep attached to the wing tip
And a relatively small amount of downwash is produced as a result of that
So:
More AoA > more lift > less thrust needed > higher fuel efficiency


As for Cg does it not make more sense to put it to be as close to the Aerodynamic Centre as possible?
Not an expert on that, but it again seems logical to me since changing speed would not have a big impact to the pitch in that case
Though according to my memory increasing thrust tends to pitch up
Would be great if anyone could explain that.

For aviation geeks:

Sweep

Swept wing is mostly used to delay wing approaching supersonic speed
Since the freestream at swept wing is = V(infinity) * cos theta
Where V(infinity) =freestream velocity and theta = angle of swept
At cruise the aircraft is flying at around 0.8Mach
So it is vital to keep the airflow (especially the negative pressure part of the wing) to be just below speed of sound in order to prevent shockwave
So yes this is to increase the fuel efficiency but not for T/O or landing

Flaps

As mentioned flaps are deployed to increase the skin friction and the camberness of the wing
Such that the aircraft could land at a relatively lower speed whilst having enough lift to stay airborne
Pitch is also the greatest when the aircraft is flying at stall speed
(If you recall, L is proportional to alpha and V)
So in order to generate the same amount of lift, the aircraft has to fly at a higher AoA
And eventually the flow no longer attaches to the wing > flow separation > stall
I am not familiar with the SOP, but a logical guess would be Vref + 10 = landing speed in case of windshear
At the same time to keep the pitch below the stall angle

Wing tip

Imagine a finite rectangular wing going through wind tunnel
Lift is produced due to the pressure difference as we expected
Since the upper part of the wing has a lower pressure
Hence at the end of the wing the high pressure airflow (bottom) tends to roll up
Vortex/ downwash is hence generated, and by Newton’s 3rd law that would decrease the effective AoA
Wing tip is then invented that the airflow will keep attached to the wing tip
And a relatively small amount of downwash is produced as a result of that
So:
More AoA > more lift > less thrust needed > higher fuel efficiency


As for Cg does it not make more sense to put it to be as close to the Aerodynamic Centre as possible?
Not an expert on that, but it again seems logical to me since changing speed would not have a big impact to the pitch in that case
Though according to my memory increasing thrust tends to pitch up
Would be great if anyone could explain that.

replies.msg:
Simple moment problem:

Assume the cg is slightly rearward to the Aerodynamic centre:

(十） —————- (X)

(Nb tailplane produces lift as well but for the sake of ease it is omitted here)

If we consider force equilibrium L = W has to be true in order to stay airborne
But with the consideration of balancing moment (pitching in this case), extra moment moment is needed to stay level.
Closer they are, less moment is needed.

With such logic the CG should be placed ahead of the AC
So that when engine failure the nose will pitch down instead of up

-

原諒我樓主我騎劫了

replies.msg:
How come u can simply omit the tailplane, u didn't mention the reason, "for the sake of ease" is not a REASON!

Back to the question, u didn't even answer why "changing speed would not have a big impact to the pitch in that case", not to mention using the maths to derive it. If u are speeding up, more airflow will pass through the tailplane, and it produces more downward force which creates a nose up moment.
However, the aircraft may or may not pitch up because of other factors affecting it's pitching moment.
